definitions.definition: Primarily physical senses.
definitions.example: (transitive) To make physical contact with; to bring the hand, finger or other part of the body into contact with. [from 14th c.]

definitions.definition: Primarily non-physical senses.
definitions.example: (transitive) To imbue or endow with a specific quality. [from 14th c.]

definitions.definition: To try; to prove, as with a touchstone.
To mark or delineate with touches; to add a slight stroke to with the pencil or brush.
(obsolete) To infect; to affect slightly.
To strike; to manipulate; to play on.
definitions.example: to touch an instrument of music

definitions.definition: To perform, as a tune; to play.
To influence by impulse; to impel forcibly.
(transitive) To make physical contact with; to bring the hand, finger or other part of the body into contact with. [from 14th c.]
(transitive) To come into (involuntary) contact with; to meet or intersect. [from 14th c.]
definitions.example: Sitting on the bench, the hem of her skirt touched the ground.

definitions.definition: (intransitive) To come into physical contact, or to be in physical contact. [from 14th c.]
definitions.example: They stood next to each other, their shoulders touching.

definitions.definition: (intransitive) To make physical contact with a thing. [from 14th c.]
definitions.example: Please can I have a look, if I promise not to touch?

definitions.definition: (transitive) To physically disturb; to interfere with, molest, or attempt to harm through contact. [from 14th c.]
definitions.example: If you touch her, I'll kill you.

definitions.definition: (transitive) To make intimate physical contact with a person.
(transitive) To cause to be briefly in contact with something.
definitions.example: He quickly touched his knee to the worn marble.

definitions.definition: (transitive) To physically affect in specific ways implied by context. [from 15th c.]
definitions.example: Frankly, this wood's so strong that sandpaper won't touch it.

definitions.definition: (transitive) To consume, or otherwise use. [from 15th c.]
definitions.example: Are you all right? You've hardly touched your lunch.

definitions.definition: (intransitive) Of a ship or its passengers: to land, to make a short stop (at). [from 16th c.]
(transitive, now historical) To lay hands on (someone suffering from scrofula) as a form of cure, as formerly practised by English and French monarchs. [from 17th c.]
(transitive or reflexive) To sexually excite with the fingers; to finger or masturbate. [from 20th c.]
definitions.example: Her parents had caught her touching herself when she was fifteen.

definitions.definition: (intransitive, obsolete) To fasten; to take effect; to make impression.
(nautical) To bring (a sail) so close to the wind that its weather leech shakes.
(intransitive, nautical) To be brought, as a sail, so close to the wind that its weather leech shakes.
(nautical) To keep the ship as near (the wind) as possible.
